Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Investigating First and Second Language Perception of Tone and Accent in Mandarin Chinese
Award.AbstractNarration:
Learning Mandarin Chinese is a major challenge for adult native speakers of English. One reason for the difficulty is the need to perceive lexical tones' pitch changes that affect word meanings in Mandarin. This research will be done in collaboration with Dr. Taomei Guo at the State Key Laboratory for Cognitive Neuroscience and Learning at Beijing Normal University, and will take advantage of the large number of advanced second language learners in Beijing, China. By measuring neural responses to spoken Mandarin sentences, the research will address two questions: First, how well can advanced second language learners perceive lexical tones? Second, how sensitive are native listeners to non-native speakers? tone errors? The answer to the first question will shed light on the difficulties adult second language learners have when attempting to reach advanced proficiency in Mandarin. The answer to the second question will clarify the practical importance of clear tone production in making second language speech comprehensible to native Chinese listeners. Results could lead to improvements in teaching and learning tones, and to the appropriate prioritization of tone mastery in an individual?s language learning regimen.

Using event-related potential (ERP) experiments, we will examine the N400 response to semantic and phonological errors in auditory stimuli. The N400 is a negative-going ERP component that peaks at approximately 400ms after the onset of stimuli and has been shown to display an increased amplitude in response to unexpected words in auditory stimuli. By examining N400 responses in first and second language listeners, we will attempt to determine whether they are equally sensitive to semantic and phonological errors, and whether that sensitivity is dependent on the identity of the speaker. Results will contribute to our understanding of the acquisition of lexical tones by second language learners and the role of accent in speech perception by native speakers of Chinese. This NSF EAPSI award supports the research of a U.S. graduate student and is funded in collaboration with the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Due to the dramatic rise of China on the international stage in recent decades, the world and the United States need to dramatically increase the number of individuals capable of understanding and communicating with native speakers of Chinese languages, most notably, Mandarin. For native speakers of English, learning the intricacies of Mandarin can be daunting. One particular challenge is learning to hear and produce the lexical tones of Mandarin. Lexical tones are pitch changes that that are used to differentiate one word from another in so-called tonal languages, such as Mandarin. For example, the single syllable “ma” spoken with a high level pitch means mother, but with a low or low-dipping pitch means horse. Currently, we understand very little about how experienced non-native speakers of Mandarin hear lexical tones, nor do we understand how native speakers of Mandarin respond to the often poorly produced tones that characterize non-native Mandarin pronunciation.

As part of the NSF-EAPSI program in the summer of 2015, I had the opportunity to carry out research aimed at exploring these issues, in collaboration with Prof. Taomei Guo at Beijing Normal University in Beijing, China. In the first study we ran three experiments to see how native English speakers—all who had learned Mandarin for at least several years and could converse fluently—perceived the tones of Mandarin in isolated syllables, in two-syllable words, and in sentences. To do this we used a mix of behavioral and electrophysiological experiments. In the syllable and word experiments, participants heard a single syllable or word and responded by pressing keys on a computer to identify what they had heard. In the electrophysiological experiment, we used electroencephalography (EEG) to record participants’ neural responses while they listened to Mandarin sentences, some of which had tonal errors on particular words. Results indicated that these advanced learners were very accurate at identifying tones on isolated syllables, looking essentially like native Chinese participants. However, for both the two-syllable word and sentence experiments, it appeared that the learners were dramatically less sensitive to tonal distinctions than the native Mandarin speakers.

These results suggest that learners and teachers of Mandarin should likely spend more time raising learners’ sensitivity to hearing tones in more complex language situations, an aspect of teaching that, anecdotally, appears to get little attention after the first semester in most language classes. Future research needs to explore why these difficulties persist for experienced learners, and if, and how, they might be effectively overcome.

In our second experiment, we tested native speakers of Mandarin on their responses to tonal pronunciation errors made by either a native Chinese speaker or a non-native speaker with a distinctively foreign-accent. We again used EEG to test participants’ responses to pronunciation errors in sentences. Results from this research were suggestive but inconclusive. Further research in collaboration with Prof. Guo is currently being undertaken to better understand how native Mandarin speakers respond to foreign-accented Mandarin. This work will potentially help to contextualize learners’ tone production difficulties so that they can be properly prioritized in classes and learning materials.
